Intro To Sass

Syntactically Awesome StyleSheets

Objectives:

  • Explain the differences between the two syntaxes: SASS and SCSS
  • Apply the basics of Sass to follow the principles of DRY
  • Contrast the pros and cons of using a CSS Preprocessor

Vocab:

**CSS Preprocessor** a program that lets you generate CSS from the preprocessorâ€™s own unique syntax. It extends the default capabilities of CSS. Examples include: Sass, LESS, Stylus and more.

**Compiler** (Technically, I think it's actually transpiling in this case...) converts our preprocessed code into css code so that the browser can understand it. For example, Webpack can use the dart-sass library to transpile SCSS to CSS

Basics:

Keep your code DRY using the following tricks:

  • defining variables that can be peppered across multiple CSS files
  • nesting elements to visibly reflect the HTML element relationships
  • break code into smaller files without affecting performance
  • grouping styles together to easily reference throughout your CSS
  • share properties between selectors
